title: R41131
content: The alternate engine program for the F-35 Lightning II fighter was a significant issue for Congress in FY2012, with implications for the defense budget and military capability. The program developed the General Electric/Rolls-Royce F136 engine as an alternative to the Pratt & Whitney F135 engine. Despite successive Administration proposals to terminate the program, Congress continued to fund it until the final FY2011 DOD budget. General Electric and Rolls-Royce ended development of the F136 engine in 2011, terminating the F-35 engine competition. On October 26, 2001, the Department of Defense selected the Lockheed Martin F-35 with the Pratt & Whitney F135 engine as the winner of the Joint Strike Fighter competition. Congress required an alternate engine, the F136, to be developed for the F-35. Despite Administration proposals to terminate the program, Congress continued funding until FY2011 when the program was officially terminated. The alternate engine program for the F-35 was terminated by the DOD in FY2011 after being rejected by Congress in previous years. Supporters of the termination argue that developing a second engine would significantly increase costs and reduce the number of F-35s that could be procured. Additionally, maintaining two engine pipelines would raise operation and support costs, especially on aircraft carriers. International interest in the F-35 does not require a second engine. Having a second engine for the F-35 is not necessary as international interest in the aircraft is already high. Congress and DOD accept the risks of using single designs across fleets, including powerplants. The development and production of the F135 engine have progressed to a point where an alternate engine program is no longer needed to hedge against technical problems. The Administration's proposal to terminate the alternate engine program for the F-35 is being opposed due to concerns about compliance with the FY2008 defense authorization act. The act requires the development and procurement of 2 options for the propulsion system to ensure competitive production for the Joint Strike Fighter. Given the importance of the F-35 in the country's strike fighter fleet, critics argue that it would be imprudent to rely solely on the F135 engine without a backup option. The proposal to terminate the alternate engine program for the F-35 is being opposed due to concerns about compliance with the FY2008 defense authorization act, which requires 2 options for the propulsion system to ensure competitive production for the Joint Strike Fighter. Critics argue that relying solely on the F135 engine without a backup option could pose risks to the entire F-35 fleet. Having a second engine in production would allow for competition in procurement and support, potentially reducing costs and promoting better engine performance and reliability. Having two production lines would also enable quicker response to strategic changes and maintain competition in future tactical aircraft engine development.
